author: Richard Barley
title: The Euroâ€™s Headache: Growth, Not Italian Politics
text:
Italy is back in the headlines and the euro is falling, giving up all its gains and more against the dollar this year to move below $1.18. But while the formation of an antiestablishment government in Rome is a headwind, there are bigger forces at work: the currency market has been rethinking the global growth story.
The bond market, not the euro, has been the chief way to bet on political and economic tensions in Europe. Even with the recent widening in the gap between Italian and German yields, the market is a long way from...
